Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.
If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submitter should include a one line description of the study.

If this is data the CCRCN curates, the study will be assigned a 128-bit universal unique identifier. Submitters should only include this if it already exists for the data. Otherwise CCRCN personnel will generate this as part of the data ingestion process.
Study start date.
Study end date.
The title of the work.
If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submitter should include a one paragraph description of the study. If this is data the CCRCN is ingesting, this can be pulled from the metadata or source text.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year spearated by underscores.

If this is data the CCRCN curates, the submitter should include five to fifteen descriptive words or phrases describing the study. If this is data the CCRCN is ingesting, this can be pulled from the metadata or source. Keywords help build some search functionality into the databases.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year separated by underscores.
Submitter’s family name.
Submitter’s first name, middle name, middle initial, or any other names.
Submitter’s current institution.
Submitter’s current email address.
Submitter’s current mailing address.
Submitter’s current phone number.
TRUE or FALSE indicating whether the author should be contacted as the corresponding author.
column5: TRUE = The author should be contacted with any further questions. FALSE = The author should not be contacted with any further questions.

column4: Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year separated by underscores.
Agency name funding the research, spelled out, no acronyms.
Code used by the agency to track the project funding.
Any other submitter-generated notes about the project funding.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year separated by underscores.

Submitters can associate multiple BibTeX style citations with the dataset. They can also include the same information by filling out following attributes in tabular form if more convenient than BibTeX formatting.
Code indicating the type of publication the study originates from.
The names of the author separated by “and”.
The year of publication or, if unpublished, the year of creation.
The title of the work.
The journal or magazine the work was published in.
The volume of a journal or multi-volume book.
The “(issue) number” of a journal, magazine, or tech-report, if applicable. (Most publications have a “volume”, but no “number” field.).
Page numbers, separated either by commas or double-hyphens.
Permanent web address where the work can be located.
Digital object identifier associated with the work.
Publisher’s address (usually just the city, but can be the full address for lesser-known publishers).
An annotation for annotated bibliography styles (not typical).
The title of the book, if only part of it is being cited.
The chapter number.
The key of the cross-referenced entry.
The edition of a book, long form (such as “First” or “Second”).
The name(s) of the editor(s).
How it was published, if the publishing method is nonstandard.
The institution that was involved in the publishing, but not necessarily the publisher.

A hidden field used for specifying or overriding the alphabetical order of entries (when the “author” and “editor” fields are missing). Note that this is very different from the key (mentioned just after this list) that is used to cite or cross-reference the entry.
The month of publication (or, if unpublished, the month of creation).
Miscellaneous extra information.
The conference sponsor.
The publisher’s name.
The school where the thesis was written.
The series of books the book was published in (e.g. “The Hardy Boys” or “Lecture Notes in Computer Science”).
The field overriding the default type of publication (e.g. “Research Note” for techreport, “{PhD} dissertation” for phdthesis, “Section” for inbook/incollection).
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year separated by underscores.
Code indicating what type of device was used to collect soil depth profiles.
Code indicating whether live roots were included or excluded from carbon assessments.
Code indicating whether or not sediment was sieved prior to carbon measurements.
If sediment was sieved, the size of sieve used.
Code indicating how the authors qualified or quantified compaction of the core.
Temperature at which samples were dried to measure dry bulk density. This can include either samples that were freeze dried or oven dried.
Time over which samples were dried to measure dry bulk density.
Sample volume used for bulk density measurements, if held constant.
Sample mass used for bulk density measurements, if held constant.
Any notable codes regarding how the authors quantified dry bulk density.
Temperature at which samples were combusted to estimate fraction organic matter.
Time over which samples were combusted to estimate fraction organic matter.
Sample volume used for loss on ignition, if held constant.
Sample mass used for loss on ignition, if held constant.
Common codes regarding loss on ignition methodology.
Code indicating whether fraction carbon was measured or estimated as a function of organic matter.
Whether or not carbonates were removed prior to calculating fraction organic carbon.
column5: FALSE = Carbonates were not removed before measuring organic carbon. TRUE = Carbonates were removed before measuring organic carbon.

column4: The method used to remove carbonates prior to measuring fraction carbon.
Code indicating the method for which fraction carbon was measured or modeled (Note: regression based models are permitted, but the use of the Bemmelen factor [0.58 gOC gOM-1] is discouraged).
Code indicating whether fraction_carbon refers to organic or total carbon.
Any other submitter defined notes describing methodologies for determining dry bulk density, organic matter fraction, and carbon fraction.
Code indicating the method used for determining radiocesium activity.
column5: alpha = Alpha counting method used. gamma = Gamma counting method used.

column4: Code indicating the method used for determining lead 210 activity.
column5: alpha = Alpha counting method used. gamma = Gamma counting method used.

column4: Code indicating the mass or accretion rate used in the excess_pb_210_model
column5: mass accumulation = Excess 210Pb modeled using mass accumulation rate. accretion = Excess 210Pb modeled using vertical accretion rate.

column4: Code indicating the model used to estimate excess lead 210.
column5: CRS = Constant rate of supply model used. CIC = Constant initial concentration model used. CFCS = Constant flux constant sedimentation model used.

column4: Code indicating the assumption used to estimate the core’s background 226Ra levels.
column5: each sample = 226Ra was measured for each sample. total core = 226Ra was measured for the total core, at asymptote = asy

column4: Code indicating the method used for determining radiocarbon activity.
column5: AMS = Accelerator mass spectroscopy used. beta = Beta counting used.

column4: Any submitter defined notes elaborating on the process of dating the core not yet made clear by the coding.
Code indicating the reference or 0 year of the age depth model.
column5: YBP = Year zero is defined as years before present, 1960 CE. CE = Year zero is set according to Common Era and Before Common Era standards. core collection date = Year zero is set as the core’s collection year.

column4: Any submitter defined notes on how the age depth model was created.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year separated by underscores.
Site identification code unique to each study.
Site description including relevant study details and political geographic units. Some of these descriptions can be automated by the ingestion code.
Maximum latitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree World Geodedic System of 1984 (WGS84). This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.
Minimum latitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.
Maximum longitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.
Minimum longitude defining a bounding box for the site in decimal degree WGS84. This can also be generated automatically by the ingestion code.

As an alternative to submitting or automatically generating a bounding box, submitters can include a shapefile (.shp) or keyhole markup language (.kml) documenting the geographic boundaries of the site. This can be converted to and stored in well known text (WTK) format.

Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating average annual salinity (Note: Palustrine and freshwater should only include tidal wetlands, or wetlands that are potentially/formerly tidal but artificially freshened due to artificial tidal restrictions).
Indicate whether salinity_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement.
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how salinity_class was determined.
Code based on submitter field observations or measurement indicating dominant wetland vegetation type.
Indicate whether vegetation_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how vegetation_class was were determined
Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating how often the coring location is inundated
Indicate whether inundation_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how inundation was determined

Date of core collection.

Positional latitude of the core in decimal degree WGS84.

Accuracy of latitude and longitude measurement, if determined and recorded.

Any relevant submitter generated notes on how latitude and longitude were determined.
Surface elevation of the core relative to defined datum.
The datum relative to which the core elevation was measured against (For a complete list of datum names and aliases please refer to the ISO Geodedic Registry https://geodetic.isotc211.org/).
Accuracy of elevation measurement, if determined and recorded
Code indicating how elevation was determined
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how elevation was determined

Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating average annual salinity (Note: Palustrine and freshwater should only include tidal wetlands, or wetlands that are potentially/formerly tidal but artificially freshened due to artificial tidal restrictions).
Indicate whether salinity_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement
Any relevant submitter generated notes on how salinity_class was determined
Code based on submitter field observations or measurement indicating dominant wetland vegetation type.
Indicate whether vegetation_class was determined using a field observation or a measurement

Code based on submitter field observation or measurement indicating how often the coring location is inundated.

Indicated whether or not the coring team believes they recovered a full sediment profile, down to bedrock, or other non-marsh interface.
Unique identifier for the study made up of the first author’s family name, as well as the second author’s family name or ‘et al.’ if more than three, then publication year separated by underscores.
Site identification code unique to each study
Core identification code unique to each site
Minimum depth of a sampling increment.
Maximum depth of a sampling increment.
Sample identification unique to the core. This should be used in the case that there are relevant lab specific sample codes, or in the case that there are multiple replicate samples.
Dry mass per unit volume of a soil sample. This does not include ash free bulk density.
Mass of organic matter relative to sample dry mass. Ash free bulk density should not be used here but should be expressed as a loss on ignition fraction.
Mass of carbon relative to sample dry mass.
Fraction of the sample depth interval reduced due to compaction.
Any submitter generated notes on compaction.
Radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for radiocesium (137Cs).
1 standard deviation of uncertainty associated with cs137_activity.
Total radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for excess lead 210 (210Pb).
1 standard deviation of uncertainty associated with total_pb210_activity.
Total radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for Radium 226 (226Ra) if measured as part of the 210Pb dating process.
1 standard deviation of uncertainty associated with ra226_activity.
Excess radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for excess lead 210 (210Pb).
1 standard deviation of uncertainty associated with excess_pb210_activity.
Radiocarbon age as estimated from AMS measurements.
Estimated uncertainty in c14_age.
Description of the material selected for radiocarbon (14C) dating.
Any relevant submitter generated notes on 14C dating process.
The isotopic signature of 13C. This is oftentimes measured along with c14_age and can be useful for analyzing carbon lability and provenance.
Radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for 7Be.
Estimated uncertainty in be_7_activity.
Radioactivity counts per unit dry weight for 241Am.
Estimated uncertainty in am_241_activity.
The age of any other dated depth horizon such as an artificial marker, pollen horizon, pollution horizon, etc.
Code indicating the type of marker.
Any other submitter generated notes about the origin of the marker.
Most likely, median, or mean age of the depth interval from submitter generated age depth model.
Minimum age of the depth interval from submitter generated age depth model.
Maximum age of the depth interval from submitter generated age depth model.
Standard deviation of age estimate from submitter generated age depth model.
Any other submitter generated notes specific to the depth interval.

A unique name for a site that corresponds to a georeferenced point.

Various notes on and descriptions of the site other than C flux, climate, photo or vegetation. May include local names for physiographic features, which may or may not appear on USGS Topographic Quadrangles.
Nation of origin of the data.
A politically defined sub-region of a country, for any country that does not describe these sub-divisions as "states".
State or territory. At output, may also include province for any contry that does not describe political subdivision as "states".
For data collected in the U.S., the county of origin within a U.S. State.
The latitudinal coordinate, in decimal degrees, to the appropriate level of spatial accuracy (up to five decimal degrees; WGS84 Latitude/Longitude datum preferred).
The longitudinal coordinate, in decimal degrees, to the appropriate level of spatial accuracy (up to five decimal degrees; WGS84 Latitude/Longitude datum preferred).
Latitude/Longitude datum against which Latitude and Longitude are reported. If left blank, WGS84 will be assumed.
Estimated accuracy of the location of the site. Site origin has a 95% or greater probability of being within this many meters of the reported location.
The elevation at the site as determined by topo map, GPS, altimeter, etc. Contributed value is assumed accurate within several meters regardless of method used.

The type of vegetation at the site, described according to the Federal Geographic Data Committee’s classification scheme (http://www.fgdc.gov/standards/projects/FGDCstandards-projects/vegetation/NVCS_V2_FINAL_2008-02.pdf). Classify the site according to the four uppermost descriptive levels (Class, Subclass, Formation, Division).
The type of vegetation at the site, described according to a TBD international classification scheme.

The type of vegetation at the site, described according to the classification scheme commonly used at the site. Indicate the scheme in the Local Vegetation Classification Type. Leave blank if unknown or no local classification applies.
Indicate the local classification scheme used at this site.
Provide references or links here if additional site-level vegetation data are available (e.g. species composition, basal area, aboveground biomass).

The type of Landscape on which the site occurs, according to USDA-NRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; p. 3-11) This information can be arranged in hierarchy above Landform and 2D Position to describe the geographic setting of the site.

The type of Landform on which the site is located. See USDA-NRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; pp. 3-12 through 3-16). This information can be nested between Landscape and 2D Position to describe the setting of the site.

2-dimensional position of the site on the Landform on which it is located. See USDANRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; pp. 3-38 through 3-41). This information supplements Landscape and Landform to describe the geographic setting of the site.
Additional notes about the Landform (e.g. microtopography) in this site.
The geologic or organic precursors to the soil at the site.
The numerical observation of aspect at the site. The compass bearing (corrected for declination) that a slope faces, looking downslope. If the site has no slope leave blank.
The cardinal direction that the slope faces at a site. Use this field if only if you do not provide the azimuth of the Site Aspect in compass degrees.

The angle of the ground surface through the site and in the direction that overland water would flow. Make observations facing downslope to avoid errors associated with some brands of clinometers. If the site has no slope leave blank.
The maximum stand age at the site in years.

If the site is forested, how mature was the stand at the time of sampling? The class may be determined by tree cores if available. If stand age is known, then 0-4 years: “young, regenerative”, 4-79 years: “even-aged, aggrading, and 80+ years: “mature even-age” or “mature, uneven-age”. Choose “not applicable” for grassland or agricultural areas. If unknown, leave blank.
Description of the assumed successional status at the site. This description is of necessity highly subjective.
The drainage class of the soil sampled at the site according to the specific terminology employed in the USDA-NRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; p. 1-10).
Measure or estimate the depth from the ground surface to the stabilized contact with freestanding water in an open bore-hole or well at the time of sampling.

The depth at which permafrost will usually thaw each summer for the site. Usually an average of many measurements over the site. This may or may not be from the thaw depth measured from individual profiles and hence may be different from Thaw Depth of the profile
The observed depth to the top of the bedrock layer
Name of nearest climate station.
The expected number of days between the last freezing temperature (0 degrees Celsius) in spring and the first freezing in fall.
The annual probability of a flood event expressed as a class according to the terminology employed in the USDA-NRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002, pg. 1-11).

The basic lithostratigraphic unit used to describe, delimit, and interpret sedimentary, extrusive igneous, metavolvanic, and metasedimentary or sediment bodies (excludes metamorphic and intrusive igneous rocks), based on lithic characteristics and stratigraphic position. A formation is commonly, but not necessarily, tabular and stratified and is of sufficient extent to be mappable at the earth's surface or traceable in the subsurface at convenient map scales.
The arithmetic average of the total annual (liquid) precipitation , preferably taken over the standard "normal" period, 1961-1990.
The arithmetic average of the daily maximum and minimum temperatures for a calendar year, preferably taken over the standard "normal" period, 1961.
The mean annual soil temperature, preferably measured at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface, or at the upper boundary of a root-limiting layer.
The number of times ponding occurs over a period of time.
Runoff potential class for the soil, assigned based on local/state/MLRA criteria.
A class rating of the overall ability of air and water to move through the soil profile. The class limits are as defined in the National Soil Survey Handbook.
The cumulative annual duration that a water table can be expected to exist in the soil.
Provide references or links to carbon flux measurements that have been conducted at the site.
Provide references or links to climate data for the site.
Special information about the site that makes it anomalous from the USDA Omernik ecoregion in which it is located.
References or links to photos from the site
Indicate information about additional soil temperature data available about this site. Please include references and links if possible.
Add links or publication references for any additional belowground data available for the site (soil chemistry, microbial measurements).
The data contributor's calculated soil organic carbon stock value for the site, cluster, profile or layer.

An indication of which portion of the profile (organic, mineral, organic + mineral) is described by the contributor's calculated soil organic carbon stock at the site, cluster, profile or layer level.
The number of profiles used in the calculation of the mean site or cluster-level soil organic carbon stocks.
The depth to which profiles were sampled to quantify the mean site, cluster, or profile calculated soil organic carbon stocks.

The standard deviation of the site, cluster, profile, or layer-level calculated soil organic carbon stock. (For layer soil organic carbon stocks, this may be based on analytical or sampling replicates of %C or bulk density measurements).
A description of the methods used to calculate (including any gap-filling) site, cluster, profile or layer soil organic carbon stocks.
A unique name for a site that corresponds to a georeferenced point.
A unique name for a single profile. This can be the same as the site name if there is only one profile at the site. For NRCS data it is the same as “Pedon ID”.
Additional notes about the profile
Description of how the individual layers of the soil profile were sampled as genetic horizons, fixed depth intervals, some combination or other.
Description of the methods used to sample the soil profile, e.g., quantitative pit, core, bucket auger, etc.
The date at which the profile was taken at the site.
Estimated accuracy of the observation date
Indicate whether this profile was part of a transect by entering "yes" or leaving the field blank.
Describe the dominant vegetation at the exact location of the profile.
The taxonomic classification of the soil profile following NRCS convention (http://soils.usda.gov/technical/classification/taxonomy/).
The NRCS soil series of the profile (http://soils.usda.gov/technical/classification/taxonomy/).
Indicate whether there is more taxonomic information for this profile by entering “yes”, otherwise leave the field blank.
The depth to the frozen surface of the profile. For Alaska sites, this applies only if sampled after August 15 and should be left blank if sampled before.
Additional notes about the soil and surface vegetation profile properties
The names of the persons who described and sampled the profile.
The data contributor's calculated soil organic carbon stock value for the site, cluster, profile or layer.

An indication of which portion of the profile (organic, mineral, organic + mineral) is described by the contributor's calculated soil organic carbon stock at the site, cluster, profile or layer level.
The number of layer soil organic carbon stock values summed to produce the profile total soil organic carbon stock.
The depth to which profiles were sampled to quantify the mean site, cluster, or profile calculated soil organic carbon stocks.

The standard deviation of the site, cluster, profile, or layerlevel calculated soil organic carbon stock. (For layer soil organic carbon stocks, this may be based on analytical or sampling replicates of %C or bulk density measurements).
A description of the methods used to calculate (including any gap-filling) site, cluster, profile or layer soil organic carbon stocks.
A unique name for a site that corresponds to a georeferenced point.
A unique name for a single profile. This can be the same as the site name if there is only one profile at the site. For NRCS data it is the same as “Pedon ID”.
A unique name for a single sampled layer. This can be a name that denotes depth, sequence, etc.
Laboratory layer sample identifier if different than the Layer Name (data contributor’s own identifier).
Was this layer/gas/fraction/sample isotopically labeled? Answer yes or leave blank.
The top (upper) depth of the layer. The surface of the nongreen (i.e. non-living) surface layer is “0”. The top of the Ohorizon should be 0.

The bottom (lower) depth of the layer. If it is uncertain that the bottom of the designated horizon was reached, enter the depth to the bottom of the sampled layer. Note that this is the same as "hzn_bot" in the NRCS database.

Follow conventions of the USDA-NRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; pp. 2-2 through 2-4). Note that datasets originally using another convention will be modified for this column. If a different convention was used it can be entered in Horizon Designation Other.
Horizon designation following a convention other than NRCS. Please document the convention in the associated Horizon Designation Other Note.
Provide a reference for the horizon designations employed if they differ from NRCS standards in the USDA-NRCSNSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002).
A description of the sampled layer. For example, a full NRCS horizon description.
Provide reference or describe the sample preparation and analysis methods used to determine carbon concentrations, whether Total Carbon, organic C, or Loss on Ignition.
Color of moist soil based on the Munsell soil color chart.
Descriptive information indicating evidence of burning within the layer.
Please reference or describe the methods used to determine bulk density.
Grams of oven-dried soil per cubic centimeter, with soil particles greater than 2 mm and roots greater that 1 cm diameter removed.
Grams of oven-dried soil per cubic centimeter, with soil particles greater than 2 mm and roots greater that 1 cm diameter included
Grams of oven-dried soil per cubic centimeter, with the content of soil particles >2mm and roots >1cm diameter estimated and subtracted.
Grams of oven-dried soil per cubic centimeter. Please document the method used in the associated Bulk Density Method including the soil particle fraction used.
Provide reference or describe the sample preparation and analysis methods used for determinations of pH if not 1:1 soil and distilled water paste or in CaCl2.
1:2 soil-CaCl2 is the pH of a sample measured in 0.01M CaCl2 at a 1:2 soil:solution ratio.
1:1 distilled water and soil paste. If pH was done by a different method, then enter it into one of the other soil pH fields.
pH measurements other than 1:1 soil and distilled water paste or in CaCl2. Please document the method in the associated pH Method.
Inorganic carbon concentration as measured or estimated by the contributor. Please document the method in the associated Processed Site Organic Carbon Content Method.
Percent by weight of soil particles greater than 0.05 mm in the sample remaining after removal of particles greater than 2 mm and roots greater than 1 cm diameter. See Gee, G.W. & Bauder, J.W. 1986.

Percent by weight of soil particles in the size range from 0.002 to 0.050 mm in the sample remaining after removal of particles greater than 2 mm and roots greater than 1 cm diameter. See Gee, G.W. & Bauder, J.W. 1986.
Percent by weight of soil particles less than 0.002 mm in the sample remaining after removal of particles greater than 2 mm and roots greater than 1 cm diameter. See Gee, G.W. & Bauder, J.W. 1986.
Provide a reference for or describe the methods used to determine coarse fragment content.

The weight fraction of particles with >2 mm diameter is reported as a gravimetric percent on a whole soil base. Please include metadata in the Coarse Fragments Method column (e.g. estimate or quantitative).
Cation Exchange Capacity. Document the extractant solution in the metadata worksheet, Lab Analysis Method.
Gravimetric water content of the sampled layer.
Water content of the soil sample expressed as a percent of total sample volume.

The data contributor's calculated soil organic carbon stock value for the site, cluster, profile or layer.

An indication of which portion of the profile (organic, mineral, organic + mineral) is described by the contributor's calculated soil organic carbon stock at the site, cluster, profile or layer level.

The standard deviation of the site, cluster, profile, or layerlevel calculated soil organic carbon stock. (For layer soil organic carbon stocks, this may be based on analytical or sampling replicates of %C or bulk density measurements).
A description of the methods used to calculate (including any gap-filling) site, cluster, profile or layer soil organic carbon stocks.
Percent by weight of carbon in the dried, milled soil sample. This measurement will typically correspond to analytical results from an elemental analyzer.

Percent by weight of carbon in a dried soil sample after acidification with HCl, OR organic carbon as estimated by Walkley-Black Modified Acid-Dichromate (e.g. ‘Organic Carbon’ in the NRCS database). Please document the method in the associated Carbon Analysis Methods.
Percent by weight of nitrogen (organic and inorganic) in an oven-dried sample (the laboratory analytical concentration).
Mass ratio of total carbon to total nitrogen, as calculated from the total carbon and total nitrogen concentrations of the bulk layer, fraction, or other sample type.

Percent by weight of the organic content of the <2mm fraction is the organic material lost after ignition. It is reported on a <2 mm base. Please document the method in the associated Carbon Analysis Method.

Use USDA NRCS conventions from the USDA-NRCSNSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; p.2-56): Record the average quantity from 3 to 5 representative unit areas. Size classes of roots being considered: very fine, < 1mm; fine, 1 – 2mm diameter.
Dry weight of roots ≤2 mm in diameter in the sample.

Error estimate for an individual layer (eg. standard deviation of analytical reps).
Soil texture classification. If no information is provided, this will be automatically generated from %sand, %silt, %clay data (coarse = ≥50% sand; fine = <50% sand).

Latitude of site reported as decimal degrees. The precision of the coordinates reported are up the user. For conversion of degree minute second values to decimal degrees, please see the following resource: https://www.latlong.net/degrees-minutes-seconds-to-decimal-degrees

Latitude and Longitude of profile locations. These fields are for reporting fine-scale (<1 km) spatial locations. For larger differences in location, the Site designation should be used. Datum should match that specified for the Site.

Indication of whether samples were collected from a natural soil (control) or one subjected to an experimental treatment. Blank values are assumed to represent control conditions.

The depth to the frozen surface of the profile. For Alaska sites, this applies only if sampled after August 15 and should be left blank if sampled before.
Generalized geologic type describing the geologic or organic precursors of the soil
General parent material chemical composition

2-dimensional position of the site on the Landform on which it is located. See USDA- NRCS-NSSC Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils (Staff 2002; pp. 3-38 through 3-41). This information supplements Landscape and Landform to describe the geographic setting of the site.
The cardinal direction that the slope faces at a site. Use this field if only if you do not provide the azimuth of the Site Aspect in compass degrees.
The numerical observation of aspect at the site. The compass bearing (corrected for declination) that a slope faces, looking downslope. If the site has no slope leave blank.

The angle of the ground surface through the site and in the direction that overland water would flow. Make observations facing downslope to avoid errors associated with some brands of clinometers. If the site has no slope leave blank.
General descriport of surface shape at soil profile sampling location.
The frequency and duration of wet periods in conditions similar to those under as defined by the USDA NRCS.

A unique name identifier for fraction. Often this is a concatination of layer_name and the frc_property
This is either the layer_name or frc_name (of a different fraction) that was used as the input to this fractionation. Specifying the frc_input allows for tracking multistep fractionations
The value of the chemical or physical property that defines the fraction as unique from the others in its scheme,
The scheme used to isolate the fraction, e.g., density, size, aggregate, chemical.
The units of measurement of the property that defines a fraction as unique, e.g. for density fractions, "g cm-3".
The upper boundary of the property that defines the fraction measured in units defined by frc_scheme_units
The lower boundary of the property that defines the fraction measured in units defined by frc_scheme_units
A specification of fractionation scheme details. Acceptable options depend on what fractionation scheme is selected.
When the fractionation scheme is a chemical extraction, this is the concentration of extractant.
Was fractionation method applied to a composite sample?
Notes on fractionation procedure.
Percent of total sample mass recovered from fractationation (note: this is for total sample, not just carbon)
Year when measurement was observed or recorded
Month when measurement was observed or recorded
Day when measurement was observed or recorded

Percent of total carbon mass isolated from fractionation.
Percent by weight of total carbon (i.e., inorganic + organic C) in the fraction
Percent by weight of organic carbon (i.e., after inorganic carbon has been removed) in the fraction
Percent weight of inorganic carbon in the fraction. This is often calculated by subrating measurements of organic carbon from total carbon.
Percent by weight of nitrogen (organic and inorganic) in an oven- dried sample (the laboratory analytical concentration).
Mass ratio of total carbon to total nitrogen, as calculated from the total carbon and total nitrogen concentrations of the bulk layer, fraction, or other sample type.
